candidates.title: WIP: Feat/pacts for verification
candidates.body:
This PR adds the following new features:

1. Adds a new Pact Source to enable pact verification using the new "pacts for verification" endpoint (https://github.com/pact-foundation/pact_broker/issues/307)
1. Pending pacts, WIP pacts and tags are now supported
1. Updates the provider CLI with new these (and other) options (currently does not allow users to specific "selectors" via the CLI, this would be easily achieved after this PR is sorted), which uses the new source
1. Adds basic environment variable support to the verifier to match the existing one

**General comments:**
* The code is still WIP and there are TODOs/Cleanups that need to happen (including moving to that streaming API where it makes sense). It does work though 👍 
* I'd specifically created a new `PactSource` because I wasn't aware of any backwards compatibility issues by changing it. If we don't need that because the only public interface is the CLI, then I'll replace the old implementation instead
* To pass the pending/verification notices to the actual verifier, I've threaded an optional `PactVerificationContext` which contains the notices alongside the Pacts and Pact source through the same process. As there are a few layers in which this passes, it's had an unfortunately side-effect of requiring a lot of functions to change. This probably also needs to be considered for backwards compatibility 
* There are a few places where duplication started appearing as a result of this (e.g. the CLI Main), I'll clean that up

If you have better/other ideas that I could try here, let me know (I considered a number of options, but they didn't feel right).

**Areas I'd like some specific feedback/assistance on:**

* Use of serde_json to serialise/deserialise the payloads. Dealing with the raw `serde_json::Value` was making this code very unreadable. Moving to to `serde_json::to_string` (and `from_value`) made this a lot nicer. Is there a reason this approach wasn't taken elsewhere?
* Where to put things. The pact_broker.rs file is getting pretty big. Currently, I've just dumped some types in there along side the new implementation to fetch pacts. Let me know if you'd like it moved
* Test approach: should we create a Pact test for this? :) Any other pointers? I've tried following previous 
* Code formatting: my editor badly wants to try and reformat the code, but doing so would have made this PR unreadable. How do you do this now?

candidates.title: Make pact_verifier_cli actually runnable by using tokio::main
candidates.body: I [commented](https://github.com/pact-foundation/pact-reference/pull/55#issuecomment-575983245) on the `pact_verifier_cli` problem you found. You're right, I had not actually tested running that executable. Here's what I believe is the fix. I have no deep explanation of how the fix works, it's just the first thing I thought of, and it seems to work.

candidates.title: Async/await
candidates.body:
~~Note that this PR should await a new major stable `reqwest` release before being merged. It should not be long. But I'm creating the PR anyway so that the essential parts can be reviewed.~~

The PR is now ready.

Lib upgrades:
* Requires Rust 1.39.0 for async/await syntax
* Upgrades tokio to 0.2
* Upgrades hyper to 0.13
* Upgrades reqwest to 0.10

API breaking changes:
~~`pact_consumer`: `trait StartMockServer` + `trait ValidatingMockServer`.~~

~~I've tried my best to make consumer tests work nicely with the recently released `tokio-0.2`. As the mock server itself is implemented asynchronously, I feel that it's correct to publicly expose its async interface, and make it compatible with the `[tokio::test]` macro. An publicly asynchronous mock server needs to be shut down explicitly, which I tried to make clear in the docs.~~

Removed `StartMockServer::create_mock_server`

There is no longer any support for starting the `pact_consumer` mock server asynchronously. This idea of mine was flawed. It's now instead always run in a separate thread. Implementation inspired by https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/blob/master/tests/support/server.rs.

This is good because it makes that API completely tokio-independent (no `async` functions exposed).

Fixes #51

candidates.title: Update to Rust 2018 edition
candidates.body:
The Rust 2018 edition removes the need to specify `extern crate`, and supports scoped macros, which I tend to like, especially for log statements: `log::info!(...)`. Also, the macro imports can be declared closer to the code that uses the macros (instead of a `macro_use` at the crate root), increasing code readability.

Some upgrades here and there (`log` needs to be at version 0.4 for scoped macro usage).

Fixes #52

candidates.title: Reqwest
candidates.body:
Using `reqwest` for pact broker HTTP client.

Fixes #37

candidates.title: Hyper upgrade
candidates.body:
My attempt at upgrading hyper to a `futures`-aware version.

Pact testing utils for rust also now futures-aware (see tests in `pact_broker.rs`).

I have not upgraded hyper in the `pact_mock_server_cli` crate. I'm proposing intruction of a more commonly used web framework there, I suggest https://github.com/seanmonstar/warp, but I feel it is outside the scope of this PR, as it's getting big enough.

candidates.title: rust/pact_consumer API overhaul
candidates.body:
Ready to merge (I hope)! ~~**Not yet ready to merge!** Please do not merge this branch yet; it's intended to provide an opportunity for ongoing feedback.~~

This PR contains my various API experiments proposed in https://github.com/pact-foundation/pact-reference/issues/17, plus a few other useful Rust tricks. I'm making an effort to keep each commit clear and independent, with a commit message describing the motivation by the change.

- [x] Create a top-level cargo workspace allowing us to run `cargo test --all` across all crates.
- [x] Make sure all the tests work.
- [x] Make a compilable and runnable version of the `pact_consumer` doctest, so that we have a metric by which to evaluate the API simplicity (and a fully working example for people using the library).
- [x] Remove the need to import `OptionalBody` directly.
- [x] Replace the `s!` macro with `Into<String>`.
- [x] Remove the need to pass hash tables to `headers` and `query`.
- [x] Figure out if we can avoid the need to wrap things in `OptionalBody`.
- [x] Think about the internal state machine, and whether or not it would be worth exposing this as part of the API types. (Diesel does something similar.) This interacts with the "builder" pattern in some important ways, though. (Don't worry, I'll explain this later!)
- [x] Provide an `Into<PactPattern>` interface (or something with a similar name), which allows the mixing of `String`, `&str`, `Regex`, `like(...)`, `serde_json::Value`, etc., when building interactions.
- [x] Experiment with some new ideas for the running & validation APIs.
- [x] Port unit tests elsewhere in the tree to the new API.

Outstanding API questions:

- [x] Do we want separate `StringPattern` and `JsonPattern` types? This would make it much easier to add `XmlPattern` someday. But it may add more complexity than we want. Experimentation required.
- [x] Q: Can we avoid needing to write `SomethingLike::new(json_pattern!("Archimedes"))` by using `Into` _without_ making it impossible to add `StringPattern` later? A: No.
- [x] What should we do about multiple values for a `query_param`? Getting a clean API for this with no hacks probably requires a bit of thought.
- [x] Add a `pact_term!` macro.
- [x] Add explicit support for `something_like` and `array_like` to the `json_pattern!` syntax.
- [x] Add a `url_for("/users/12")` method that calls `join` and `expect` with a relative path.
- [x] Add helpers like `content_type`, `json`, `not_found`, `created`, etc.
- [x] Q: Should we shorten the name of `json_pattern!` to something like `json_pat!`? A: Probably not.
- [x] Q: Should we rename `array_like!` (matches Ruby) to `each_like!` (matches JavaScript)? What about `something_like!` to `like!`?
- [x] Q: Do regex expressions all need `^` and `$`, or is that supplied by Ruby? A: Required on the Rust side.
- [x] Can we add `min` to the `array_like!` macro without too much messing around?
- [x] Add `charset=utf-8` (with case insensitive regex) to default JSON header.
- [x] Add helper to strip null object fields from `serde_json::Value`.
- [x] Figure out what's going on in the Ruby code, especially re: `min` and `match`.
- [x] ~~Add output directory configuration.~~ Will move to another PR.
- [x] Spent 10 Oct 2017 writing code against this API, fix any remaining issues, and submit this PR by EOD.

Other cleanup:

- [x] Add a helper method for `.get_or_insert_with(Default::default)`, and clean up everywhere.
- [x] Add an example testing with a domain object serialized to JSON.
- [x] Update top-level crate documentation to contain a brief explanation of what Pact is and why it's cool, for people who discover this crate at http://docs.rs/pact_consumer/

candidates.title: Remove deprecated json lib
candidates.body: Migration of remaining pact modules over to Serde JSON serialisation library (this completes issue #7)

candidates.title: Replace deprecated rustc_serialize json library with serde json library
candidates.body:
Migration of rustc_serialize to serde for json (de)serialisation in pact.

Removal of rustc_serialize has been completed for `pact-matching` but has not been completed yet for the other pact modules.

chosen_pr.title: Hyper upgrade
chosen_pr.body:
My attempt at upgrading hyper to a `futures`-aware version.

Pact testing utils for rust also now futures-aware (see tests in `pact_broker.rs`).

I have not upgraded hyper in the `pact_mock_server_cli` crate. I'm proposing intruction of a more commonly used web framework there, I suggest https://github.com/seanmonstar/warp, but I feel it is outside the scope of this PR, as it's getting big enough.
